#Text=Veit Stoss
#Text=Wooden Altar of Veit Stoss at St Mary 's Church in Kraków
#Text=Blind Veit Stoss with granddaughter
#Text=by Jan Matejko ( 1865 ) , National Museum in Warsaw
#Text=Veit Stoss

#Text=( also : Veit Stoß and Stuoss ; Polish : Wit Stwosz ; before 1450 – about 20 September 1533 ) was a leading German sculptor , mostly in wood , whose career covered the transition between the late Gothic and the Northern Renaissance .
#Text=His style emphasized pathos and emotion , helped by his virtuoso carving of billowing drapery ; it has been called " late Gothic Baroque " . [ 1 ]

column1: #Text=He had a large workshop and in addition to his own works there are a number by pupils .
#Text=He is best known for the altarpiece in St. Mary 's Basilica in Kraków , Poland .
#Text=Life
#Text=Stoss was born at Horb am Neckar before 1450 ; his exact date of birth is unknown though it may have been in 1447 .
#Text=Nothing about his life is known for certain before 1473 when he moved to Nuremberg in Franconia and married Barbara Hertz .

#Text=Their eldest son Andreas was born there before 1477 , when Stoss moved to Kraków , the royal capital of Poland , where he was commissioned to produce the enormous polychrome wooden Altar of Veit Stoss ( Ołtarz Wita Stwosza ) at St Mary 's Church in Kraków .
#Text=His son Stanisław was also a sculptor .
#Text=Veit lived and worked in Kraków for the next twenty years .
#Text=His name is usually polonized as Wit Stwosz . [ 2 ]
#Text=In Kraków
#Text=The altar in Kraków was completed in 1489 , and was the largest triptych of its time .
#Text=Like Stoss ' other large works , it required a large workshop including specialized painters and gilders . [ 3 ]
#Text=Other important works from Stoss ' period in Poland were the tomb of Casimir IV in Wawel Cathedral , the marble tomb of Zbigniew Oleśnicki in Gniezno , and the altar of Saint Stanislaus .
#Text=The Polish court was more aware of Italian styles than Nuremberg patrons of that time , and some of Stoss ' Polish work used Renaissance classical ornament . [ 4 ]
#Text=During World War II , on the order of Hans Frank – the Governor-General of that region of occupied Poland – the dismantled Altar was shipped to the Third Reich around 1941 .
#Text=It was rediscovered in 1945 in Bavaria , hidden in the basement of the heavily bombed Nuremberg Castle . [ 5 ]
#Text=The High Altar underwent major restoration work in Poland and was put back in its place at the Basilica ten years later . [ 2 ]
#Text=Nuremberg
#Text=In 1496 , Stoss returned to Nuremberg with his wife and eight children .
#Text=He reacquired his citizenship for three gulden and resumed his work there as a sculptor .
#Text=Between 1500 and 1503 he carved an altar , now lost , for the parish church of Schwaz , Tyrol of the " Assumption of Mary " .

column1: #Text=In 1503 , he was arrested for forging the seal and signature of a fraudulent contractor and was sentenced to be branded on both of his cheeks and prohibited from leaving Nuremberg without the explicit permission of the city council .
#Text=He was pardoned in 1506 by Emperor Maximilian and restored of his civil rights . [ 6 ]
#Text=Angelic Salutation
#Text=( 1517 – 1518 ) in the St. Lorenz Kirche , Nuremberg
#Text=The Angel Raphael and the young Tobias . Limewood . 97cm ( 38in ) , ( Germanisches Nationalmuseum , Nuremberg )

#Text=Despite the prohibition he went to Münnerstadt in 1504 , to paint and gild the altarpiece that Tilman Riemenschneider had left in plain wood ten years earlier , presumably according to his contract ( unlike Stoss , his workshop did not include painters and gilders ) .
#Text=Leaving wood sculpture unpainted was a new taste at the time , and " perhaps the tastes of the city council were somewhat provincial .

#Text=Even Giorgio Vasari , who did not think much of artists north of the Alps , praised it in his Le Vite and called it  a miracle in wood " , though misattributing it . [ 8 ]

column1: #Text=Veit Stoss was buried at St. Johannis cemetery in Nuremberg . [ 9 ]
#Text=His artistic legacy was continued by his son Stanisław . [ 10 ]
#Text=In popular culture
#Text=Veit Stoss is featured in Judith Weir ' s opera , The Black Spider .
#Text=He is one of the singing sculptors in Act 3 Scene 2 inside the Wawel Cathedral .
#Text=He is shown chiseling at the tomb of King Casimir IV .
#Text=There is a Polish book ( 1913 ) and film ( 1961 ) Historia żółtej ciżemki ( The story of a yellow crakow ) [ 11 ] about Veit Stoss in Cracow .
#Text=Notes and references
